awd_titl_txt: Workshop to Develop US Leadership in the Emerging Area of Soft Evolutionary Materials; Washington University; St. Louis, Missouri; 13 October 2019
awd_abstract_narration:
Evolutionary materials that can change their form and function on demand have been at the heart of many technological revolutions, including lasers and fast actuators. A new materials revolution is underway, with evolutionary materials that not only change form and function, but also happen to be soft so that they can be used in entirely new technologies that interface with humans. Many of these materials challenge our understanding of what materials actually are, and blur the boundaries between a material and a structure. Soft, evolutionary materials hold much promise for a new generation of devices and cures. Establishing US dominance in this area and harnessing the potential benefits for prosperity and the general welfare will require developing a set of leaders across career stages and backgrounds, and setting the research agenda for this emerging field of soft, evolutionary materials. The daylong workshop funded by this grant will bring together established experts and young investigators from around the US to advance the understanding of soft matter and its application across a broad range of disciplines, and will develop the research agenda in this emerging field. 

The focus will be developing the tools needed to model, design with, and optimize these new materials that change function and/or form in response to external stimuli. The workshop will develop an agenda in multi-materials, metamaterials, multi-component materials, and polymers. Bringing together experts across these sub-disciplines constitutes a major opportunity for developing American leadership in soft evolutionary materials. The gathering will afford ample opportunity for students to interact with internationally leading professors both scientifically and socially through a mentoring lunch and opportunities for one-on-one meetings with NSF program managers associated with the sister meeting, the Society of Engineering Science Annual Meeting. The workshop will thus enable investigators across a broad range of career stages to gain insight into pathways to success in these areas. A specific aim is to help young investigators maximize career development opportunities at this conference by providing them comfortable foundations of both scientific background and networking. The successes and failures of the workshop to achieve this goal will be assessed carefully through a survey to be completed by participants.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Soft materials that evolve their function or form in response to external stimuli hold much promise for the next generation of soft robotics, human-machine interfaces, prosthetics, implants, and wearable devices. At the core of these possibilities is the concept of architected materials with functional or structured components that enable properties outside of those that can be found amongst naturally occurring materials, and the concept of active responses that enable materials to evolve to new states or configurations in response to non-invasive stimuli. These materials can actuate, measure, transform, respond, and heal on demand, and enable a broad new set of applications. This symposium assembled a diverse group of leaders from across US academia to encapsulate the state of the art in the development and application of these materials, and to identify key opportunities for the research agenda needed to advance US leadership in this important, emerging field.

Background:

In nature, materials that interact with delicate and valuable organisms typically fall at the extremes of stiffness and hardness, with soft materials such as the tissues of fingers and the placenta at one extreme, and teeth and claws at the other. The soft matter revolution has in part been fueled by a desire to make engineering products for gentle handling, from agricultural equipment to protective equipment to prosthetics to medical devices, more like fingers and less like teeth. This work has been a key driver in the expansion of the now widely used, low modulus hydrogels and foams that now populate the lower extremes stiffness and density amongst all materials. 

Another important feature of useful soft materials in nature is that they can often contract actively, sense their environment, and change in response to sensation or external control. These changes include a range of electrophysiological responses, as in muscles, nerve tissues, and electric eels; emission of light through bioluminescence; changes to optical properties, as in certain squids; and stimulus of healing responses. An emerging frontier in the evolution of manufacturing is the development of materials that can similarly evolve shape, change physical properties, or heal in response to external stimuli. This ?biologicalization? of materials and manufacturing underlies the development of a new generation of soft, evolutionary materials, critical to the new generation of soft robots, human-machine interfaces, prosthetics, implants, sensors, and wearable devices. These soft, evolutionary materials are a class of active matter, in which external stimuli such as heat, light, voltage, electromagnetic fields, pH, and stretch spark an ?internal drive? that triggers desirable changes, not unlike active matter in animals. The materials are often functional or structured metamaterials, with mesoscale features and macroscale folding leading to properties otherwise unattainable in a bulk solid.

Like fibrous composite materials before them, soft, evolutionary materials add function and performance at the expense of manufacturing ease. These active materials must often be manufactured with the structure and final engineering application in mind. For such systems, the distinction between material and structure is often blurred. Features that extend material longevity such as self-healing characteristics must be engineered into a structure from its inception. In all cases, the materials and design engineer must be cognizant of the sensitivity of the mesoscale features of these materials that endow them with functionality, and of the possibility of deactivating the evolutionary capacity of these materials during manufacture.

This symposium was therefore held to ensure that the US research community develops the diverse set of researchers across scientific disciplines needed to enable progress in these fields and translation of results to industry.

Intellectual merit:

A diverse set of experts from across the US was assembled, hailing from all across regions, and of a great variety of backgrounds and career stages. The connections made at the event have fueled several new research collaborations, and have led to the development of a proposed research agenda for the US to retain dominance in this important new field. 

Broader Impacts:

The gathering was held in conjunction with the 2019 Society of Engineering Science annual meeting in October of 2019 at Washington University in St. Louis. To maximize impact across the field of engineering science, the workshop was integrated with the Society of Engineering Science meeting, with most participants in the workshop also participating in related technical sessions at the conference. To help bring visibility to the field and to engage researchers across career stages, a mentoring session was held in which younger researchers and trainees met and networked with the workshop participants in a small group settings over lunch. The event assembled a broad and diverse set of researchers from across career stages, and supported career development for this diverse group. The event provided a platform for focusing research on topic areas that can provide a foundation for US dominance in this important new area.
